INDEPENDENT AND PROGRESSIVE

Nelsons' Directory Company, Inc., publishers of this city directory and the world's largest independent publishers of city directories, is in no way connected with any national association or directory "trust." Its policies are laid down with a view to serving the individual directory subscriber and the general public. It is a progressive company, constantly on the alert to improve its service.

The LARN type of city directory was originated by Nelsons' Directory Company, Inc. While many publishers have been content to rest on their laurels, issuing the same type of directory used 30 years ago, the Nelsons' organization has led the way to the production of a modern city directory to meet modern selling and credit conditions.

Newspapers, chambers of commerce, merchants associations and individual business concerns are invited to write for particulars concerning this type of directory service. In the future, as in the past. Nelsons' directories will stand for the highest ideals in public service.

NELSONS' DIRECTORY COMPANY, INC.

This population secured by an actual count of persons residing in territory covered by a House-to-House Canvass under Nelsons' Modern LARN plan.

EXPLANATION

All people sixteen years or over are listed. Wives are listed with husbands, the wife being shown in parenthesis as follows: Smith Robt R (Mary L). The number of children under sixteen years is shown after the wife's name as follows: Smith Robt R (Mary L) 3. The both in the resident directory and the householders' directory designates ownership of the home.

In case of a natural widow this fact is shown with the name of the deceased husband in parenthesis, whenever possible, as follows: Smith Mary L (wid Robt R).

The occupation and place of employment are shown as follows: Smith Robert R (Mary L) elk Hub Clothing Co.

The residence of each person is shown "h" denoting a householder or head of the family, "r" denoting people in the home.

Married women, engaged in some other occupation than housekeeping, are listed individually in addition to their regular listing with their husbands, as follows: Smith Mary (Mrs Robt R) bkpr Henry Jones & Co r 210 Main.

Names in heavy type denote patrons of the directory and are usually the leading firms in each line of business.

Colored is shown by a . The publishers are very careful in using this, but do not assume any responsibility in case of error.

This directory contains all the regular departments of the modern city directory and many features used by no other publisher in the United States.

A numerical telephone directory will be found in the back of the directory listing each telephone according to number.

The classified business directory lists each firm according to line of business. The numerical street directory lists each street alphabetically and each house according to number, with the street intersections as they appear. After each householder's name will be found his telephone number. In case he has no telephone the nearest telephone may be found. The denotes householders who own the house in which they live. By using the street guide as a mailing list, a thorough coverage of the city will be obtained without any duplication of names. The buyers' guide carries the printed messages of the city's leading business and professional firms arranged alphabetically according to classifications. This directory shows the approximate population and environs at the present time.

NELSONS' DIRECTORY COMPANY, INC.

INTRODUCTION

Nelsons' Directory Company, Inc., publishers of your city directory, takes pleasure in presenting the 1957 edition to the general public. A large force of trained enumerators and solicitors worked diligently in the preparation of this volume and we are confident that the result is an authentic and useful city directory.

We have faith in the continued growth of your city and we believe that our directory will take its place as one of the vital instruments for the advancement of your community. Subsequent editions will be issued promptly and regularly.

This volume is an example of the LARN type of city directory as originated and developed by the Nelsons' Directory Company, Inc. In the modern business world with its greatly changed sales and credit systems, the old type of directory has become completely obsolete. In adopting the directory to modern conditions the Nelson organization is the pioneer. The excellent city directory which your city now has is the result of the progressive spirit of this company and its accurate interpretation of modern business requirements.

SIX DIVISIONS OF THE BOOK The principal parts of the Nelsons' Directory are as follows: 1. The Buyer's Guide and Civic Section is made up of the advertisements of the leading business firms of the city, announcements of churches, clubs, lodges, associations and schools, and professional cards of public-spirited lawyers, physicians and dentists. The display spaces have been carefully grouped and indexed under headings which are descriptive of the business engaged in by each firm. The Buyer's Guide, when properly arranged and distributed, is of tremendous value in the building of business in the community. 2. The Resident Directory contains most of the data concerning the individual. The wife's name is given in parenthesis, and the number of dependents under 16 is shown as well as the ownership of homes. This is followed by position, place of employment and home oddress. 3. The Householders' Directory contains a complete directory of streets and avenues, properly located, gives the names of all householders arranged as they come upon the streets and avenues, indicates ownership of property. 4. The Business Directory and List of Nationally Advertised Brands contains the names of all business firms, professional people and non-profit organizations, properly classified. In this division are also listed the names of nationally advertised brands of merchandise, with the name of the local agents or distributors.

INTRODUCTION

5. The Numerical Telephone Directory contains telephone numbers arranged in numerical sequence.

6. Rural Route Directory contains names of all rural residents.

SPECIAL LARN FEATURES The following valuable information which appears in the LARN type of directory is not to be found in the old-style city directory: Number of dependents under sixteen; Designation of home ownership; Nationally Advertised Brands; Numerical Telephone Directory; Telephone Numbers on Street Guide. Rural Route Directory In addition to these valuable features, the LARN type of directory is more conservatively styled, printed on better paper and more beautifully bound, arranged for more convenient use and cantains a much more complete civic section.

THE HOUSEHOLDERS' SUPPLEMENT After including every conceivable feature which would tend to make the directory as useful and attractive as possible, the originators of the LARN type of directory made one more bold stroke--they established a guaranteed HOME circulation for advertising matter by issuing the Hauseholders' Supplement and delivering it to the homes of the community. Every advertisement which appears in Nelsons' Directory also appears in the Householder's Supplement, making the Nelsons' Directory "America's greatest dollar-for-dollar advertising medium" today.

NELSONS' DIRECTORY COMPANY, INC.

In 1840, General Lewis Lawrence Griffin purchased 800 acres of land and reserved 22 of these for public buildings, churches, parks, a parade ground and an athletic field. Few Georgia cities have been planned so meticulously. William McIntosh, well known Chief of the Creek Indians, blazed the first trail through this region 28 years before this historical purchase.

Today, Griffin is a modern city of 20,472 with a metropolitan population of approximately 27,000. It is the county seat of Spalding County.

Primarily it is a textile city with some two-thirds of the non agricultural workers being employed in textile mills. Food processing is the second largest employment category. Included in this latter is the Pomona Products Company, the largest pimiento pepper canning operation in the world.

The first textile mill opened in Griffin in 1883, and the industry has provided a payroll for the area without which the transition to urban life and modernized agriculture could never have taken place. In 1900 there were 1,000 industrial wage earners in Griffin and annual wages were less than a quarter of a million dollars; today there are approximately 8,000 on industrial payrolls with more than $17,000,000 as an annual payroll.

An aerial view of Griffin, Ga., a manufacturing city of 29,666 population. This is the downtown section and part of the southern residential area. In the outlying areas, there are approximately 50 manufacturing plants.

This is typical of the many beautiful homes located in Griffin. This city is sometimes called the city of beautiful homes.

The first bank in Griffin was a rock house, 10 by 12 feet, guarded at night "by a big bulldog procured for the purposes." Banking in Griffin soon out grew the powers of the bulldog and today deposits in the banks total more than 17 million dollars. But between the days of the little rock bank and the beginning of modern Griffin, the War of 1861-65 intervened, confiscating all property in slaves and destroying completely the capital of Griffin that had been turned into Confederate bonds and currency. A special census in June 1865, taken for the information of the Federal Command, revealed that 37 per cent of the population of Griffin and Spalding County was destitute.

Griffin's revival dates from the founding of the Griffin Manufacturing Company in 1883, capital totaling $100,000 was raised locally and a cotton mill was built. At about this time a cotton mill in nearby Upson County closed and the operatives moved to the new Griffin Mill. Around this nucleus of skilled textile labor the company assembled a labor force from the surrounding farms.

Griffin could never have accomplished its amazing feat of bootstrap economics without a keen awareness of the interdependence of ail phases of its economic life. That Griffin has succeeded where other areas may have failed is not due to the success of either industry or agriculture but is instead directiy attributable to the mutual success of both.

Today's Griffin in Brief Review - - Agriculture -- The Georgia Experiment Station on the outskirts of town is a mecca for southern farmers studying modern agricultural methods; it has added immeasurably to the economy of the south by developing new plants like Empire Cotton, Truehart Perfection Pimientos, Hunt muscadines and a new hybrid corn, Georgia 101. The station improved food processing that has created new industries for Georgia.

Area -- The city limits of Griffin cover on area of 6.7 square miles while Spalding County comprises an area of 128,640 acres of land with an area of 201 square miles.

Churches -- The metropolitan area has a total of 45 churches representing ten denominations. According to the latest church census 60% of the total population hold church memberships.

Climate -- Griffin has an ideal climate of relative cool summers and mild winters. Its geographical position, well south of the Temperate Zone, and its proximity to large bodies of semi-tropical water, naturally gives a mild pleasant climate. The average daily wind movement is 5.22 m.ph. The warm average mean winter temperature of 52.88 degrees and the cool average mean summer temperature of 74.15 degrees with adequate year round average rainfall of 39.8 inches, provides excellent weather conditions for comfortable living with plentiful days of sunshine and a long growing season.

Communications Griffin has two local radio stations: Radio Station WKEU (250 watts) and WHIE (1,000 watts). The Griffin Daily News with a circulation of 6,593 is printed daily six days a week. Telephone and Telegraph service is of the highest caliber.

Education -- The consolidated schools of Griffin and Spalding County, accredited by the State of Georgia and the Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, offer new opportunities in an expanded education system. With required and elective courses in junior and senior high school, together

Dundee Mills, manufacturer of Dundee Towels, is second largest towel producer in the world.

This aerial view shows the campus of Griffin High School. Griffin and Spalding County have a consolidated school system second to none. Recreation is an important phase of community life in Griffin. Shown above is the entrance to the municipal pool located at the beautiful Griffin park and playground.

with vocational training, the educational progress of students is carefully supervised to obtain maximum advantages and to maintain the high scholastic standing in the state. Modern structures are complete with laboratory equipment and machinery, visual aids, arts and crafts, drama, school bands. Other activities provide a variety of educational and healthful interest.

New schools have been completed for both Negro and White students under more than $1,000,000.00 school expansion program and a 2nd $1,250,000.00 building pragram is at present underway. The Griffin and Spalding County School system has 23 grammar schools, one junior high school and two senior high schools. Approximately 7,543 students attend these schools under the supervision of 250 teachers. Griffin is centrally located for the many colleges and universities located in Georgia: Agnes Scott, Emory University, Georgia Tech, Wesleyan College and Mercer University are within a 50 mile radius; with the University of Georgia, Shorter College, Georgia State College for Women, North Georgia College, Breneau and West Georgia College only short distances further.

Electric Power -- Electric power is supplied to the area by the Georgia Power Company and is distributed in the Metropolitan area by the city owned power system. There are three transmission lines with 110,000 volts and two with 44,000 volts. Power supply is no problem for any industrial expansion plant.

Fire Protection -- The Griffin Fire Department has 26 competent men, trained at the State Fire College in Atlanta, and excellent fire fighting equipment. The equipment includes; one 1,000 gallon pumping engine, two 750 gallon pumping engines, two 500 gallon pumping engines and one 55' aerial. A second station is located in the West Griffin area.

Government -- Griffin has had a city management form of municipal government since 1918, composed of a city manager appointed by three commissioners elected by the citizens for three years alternated terms. Spalding County is

The Griffin Water Works Building, beautifully landscaped is one of the first sites visitors see as t ey enter the city limits of Griffin. This plant produces 7,000,000 gallons of water per ay or use of Griffin citizens.

Although Griffin is known as an industrial center, agriculture plays an important role in the economy of the county. In the picture above, farmers are shown cutting grain at harvest time.

governed by three county commissioners each of whom is elected by the people for six year terms with election of one commissioner each two years. So closely ore the City and County dependent for community development services and economic progress, the governments of each work in close harmony with the other. Both governments work with local industry and are active in projects to secure new industry.

Health -- A combined city and county Health Department has a well trained staff of specialists, housed in modern and well-equipped buildings. Medical, health and child care services are provided and two clinics are operated. Ail health and medical facilities have been constructed for expanded operations as the needs arise. The community has 28 doctors, eight dentists and numerous other specialists practicing locally.

Hospital -- The new Griffin-Spalding County multi-million dollar hospital is one of the most modern and well-equipped in the state. Completed in 1950 and operated jointly by the city and county, it serves an area of a 30 mile radius. There are facilities for 110 bed patients, emergency service, maternity, and surgical and x-ray section. Employed there are 31 registered nurses and 39 nurse's aides.

Housing -- Housing in the vicinity of Griffin is considered to be adequate for current needs. There are approximately 200 low rent public housing units for low income bracket families. There are no great inadequacies existing and there has been no need for building programs to supply the area with housing.

Police Protection -- Griffin has an adequate police force with detectives, patrol and traffic divisions. The 31 well trained officers have provided Griffin with an extremely low incident rate. This force works in harmony with the Sheriff and the State Patrol officers located in the county.

Recreation -- Recreational facilities in and nearby Griffin affer an abundance of facilities for relaxation and enjoyment of outdoor sports. City parks of hundreds of areas provide recreation for both races. The White Municipal Park includes an eighteen hole golf course, which is one of the finest in the State, tennis courts, swimming pool, picnic grounds, play areas, and other facilities. The Negro Municipal Park provides an outdaor cancrete swimming pool, bath houses, an open air dance pavilion, beautiful picnic grounds, tennis courts, play areas and other facilities. Jackson Lake in adjoining Butts County, offers swimming boating and fishing. 100 private lakes in Spalding County are centers of social life, easily accessible by a net work of county paved roads. Griffin is but a few hours by automobile from the mountain resorts in North Georgia and seashores on both the Atlantic and Gulf beaches.

Topography -- The pleateau on which Griffin is situated 980 feet above sea level affords the area unusual drainage advantages.

Transportation -- Air: Griffin is located approximately 35 miles south of the Atlanta Municipal Air Field and is joined to the field by the four lane super highway. Twelve major air routes from across the nation join in Atlanta: (1) New York; (2) Chicago; (3) Dallas-Los Angeles and Trans. Pacific; (4) New OrleansMexico City and South America; (5) Tallahasee-Tampa; (7) Charleston; (8) Cincinnati; (9) Savannah; (10) Pittsburg-Buffalo; (11) Kansas City; (12) Denver. A total of 214 mail, passenger and cargo planes are scheduled in and out of Atlanta daily. Five major airlines operate in Georgia.

Motor Freight -- Five major motor express lines, handling interstate and intrastate freight shipments operate shipments from Griffin: Akers Motor Lines, Georgia Highway Express, Great Sauthern Trucking Company and Perkins Freight Lines, Johnson Transfer Company.

Water -- The Griffin water supply is Flint River which originates near East Point, Georgia, forty miles north of Griffin. The river is capable of supplying 15 million gallons of water per day. Under the present system the filtered water supply provides 7,000,000 gallons per day.

Th Flint River Regional library is headquarters for several counties and has more than 30,000 volumes.
